greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Omega(2n-1) (number of prime factors of the n-th odd number, counted with multiplicity).
comment: Omega(n) of the odd integers follows a pattern similar to A001222, with 4 maxima instead of 2 - i.e. between 2^n and (2^(n+1) - 1) there are two numbers with exactly n factors (2^n and 2^(n-1) * 3) while the odd integers have 4 maxima (3^n, 3^(n-1) * 5, 3^(n-1) * 7, 5^2*3^(n-2)) between 3^n and 3^(n+1) - 1.
link: Antti Karttunen, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
program: (PARI) a(n) = bigomega(2*n-1) \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jul 26 2013, edited to reflect the changed starting offset by _Antti Karttunen_, May 31 2017
xref: One more than A285716 (after the initial term).
results.author: _Andrew S. Plewe_, Feb 20 2004
ext: Starting offset changed to 1 and the definition modified respectively. Also values of the initial term and of term a(92) (= 2, previously a(91) = 1) corrected by _Antti Karttunen_, May 31 2017
